content.rendered:
I have to admit, I don’t often think to praise God as I should. One might think that it would be easier to remember to praise God when things are going well. But I find that it’s easier to remember when things aren’t going as I would want.

God is worthy of praise. It has nothing to do with my being worthy to praise God.

The book of Psalm is one of my favorite books in the Bible. Much of the book is praise to God, and much of it was written in times of distress. Below are just a few.

“Bless the Lord, O my soul: and all that is within me, bless his holy name.” —Psalm 103:1

“Because thy lovingkindness is better than life, my lips shall praise thee. Thus will I bless thee while I live: I will lift up my hands in thy name.” Psalm 63:3-4

“I will extol thee, my God, O king; and I will bless thy name for ever and ever.” — Psalm 145:1

Jesus’ decibels asked the Lord how they ought to pray. Jesus starts off a prayer saying, “…Our Father which art in heaven, Hallowed be thy name.” Matthew 6:9. God is set apart. Unlike his creation, God cannot lie and he cannot sin. God is holy, and we need to remember this.

Isaiah 25: 1 says, “O Lord, thou art my God; I will exalt thee, I will praise thy name; for thou hast done wonderful things; thy counsels of old are faithfulness and truth.”

Praising God likely won’t change our circumstances, but it has the power to change how we see our circumstances. It can help us take our eyes off of the problems that we face and put them on the one who is bigger than our problems. It’s something that I need to remember to do more often.
